awd_abstract_narration: A conventional scanning electron microscope will be acquired for                                                                                                use in a multiuser, campus-wide facility at Mississippi State                   University.  The high resolution achievable with a research-grade                                                                                               scanning electron microscope is essential to the projects of six                                                                                                major users and six minor users from diverse disciplines.  The                  former projects deal with the morphology of (1) fossil ostracods,                                                                                               (2) sensory receptors of water mites, (3) scent organs of moths,                                                                                                (4) seed coverings, (5) moth sensory organs and organs of host                  plants, and (6) fossil and recent diatoms.  The projects of the                 six minor users deal with (1) intestinal nutrient transport in                  piglets, (2) particle sizing, (3) fungal infection of plant                     tissue, (4) paleomagnetism, (5) fungus and nematode colonization                                                                                                of roots, and (6) crustacean blood clotting and wound healing.
